title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Retirement, Cryptocurrency, Weird LA Museums
text:
0 COMMENTS Retirees often underestimate their future spending, writes Neal Templin .
Navigating retirement can be difficult for lots of reasons. One of the biggest is that it forces people to make plans based on spending assumptions that won’t become a reality for decades. Guessing wrong can be the difference between a comfortable retirement and one that is a struggle.
Financial advisers say some of the most frequent mistakes people make when estimating how much they’ll need for retirement include how much they can help out family, paying for big-ticket items like cars or home repairs, and health care.
Below, some of the best analysis and insight from WSJ writers and columnists, and occasionally beyond, on investing, the wealth-management business and more.
TALKING POINTS 
The Trophy Homes Linked to Chinese Conglomerate HNA Group: As Chinese conglomerate HNA Group works to raise capital, its executives and a company headed by the CEO’s brother own trophy homes throughout metro New York , including four pricey residences at One57.
PLANNING & INVESTING 
Why Volatile Markets Are Good News for Careful Investors: February’s selloff and subsequent turbulence have restored some normality.
Cryptocurrency Firms, Investors Seek Exemption From SEC Oversight: Andreessen Horowitz and other venture-capital backers of digital-currency firms lobby regulators.
BUSINESS & PRACTICE 
Robo Adviser Wealthfront Cuts a Fee to Appease Angry Investors: The firm plans to cut the fee on a new investment product that led some clients and consumer advocates to question its commitment to a low-cost model .
SEC Votes to Propose Stricter Broker Standards: The commission’s Democrats blast the plan as weak and likely to maintain the status quo.
TRAVEL & LIFESTYLE 
Surreal Los Angeles: Touring the City’s Strangest Museums: In Los Angeles, a city unfettered by tradition and well-versed in whimsy, oddball museums flourish .
